author: vneedham@thehill.com (Vicki Needham)
title: Unemployment claims fall to 42-year low
text:
Unemployment claims fall to 42-year low Getty Images By Vicki Needham - 10/15/15 10:29 AM EDT 
American workers filed the fewest unemployment claims in 42 years last week, a sign that the labor market remains healthy despite a slower pace of hiring over the past couple of months. 
Weekly applications for unemployment benefits fell 7,000 to a seasonally adjusted 255,000, the lowest level since November 1973, as employers hang on to their workers, the Labor Department said Thursday. ADVERTISEMENT The four-week average, a better indicator as to where the job market is headed, dropped 2,250 to 265,000, the lowest level since Dec. 15, 1973.
Job gains slowed in August and September — to 136,000 and 142,000, respectively — with energy sector employment hit by low oil prices and manufacturers facing higher costs on their exports because of the dollar's strength. 
Despite the slowdown, economists are optimistic the U.S. economy's underlying strength will help push up wages in early 2016 and move toward full employment by next summer. 
Meanwhile, consumer spending is in a holding pattern and confidence has shifted into neutral while the economy works through a slower patch fueled by global financial turmoil. 
But even amid broader global uncertainty, businesses have opted not to shed their employees. 
The labor market's fluctuations combined with a worldwide economic slowdown may give the Federal Reserve pause about whether to raise short-term interest rates by the end of the year.
